citeinfo.origin: National Park Service, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Resource Mangement and Science
citeinfo.title: Polygon Feature Class of Frank Miller's 1938 Forest Types and Disturbance History Map at Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Tennessee and North Carolina

descript.abstract: This is a vector polygon file showing the historic forest types and disturbances at Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Tennessee and North Carolina. The data was collected from a historic map drawn in 1938 by Frank Miller, the park's Assistant Forester. The map was scanned using a Vidar color scanner and the digital images were brought into ArcMap. The map was originally divided into 2 panels, thus there were 2 separate image files. Each image was Georectified, Clipped and then the Mosaic tool was employed to create a single large map image. Two feature classes, one a point feature class and the other a polyline feature class, were then created. The polyline class was used to digitize the boundary of each area of vegetation and a point containing the attributes of each area was placed within. After digitizing, the polyline layer was converted to a polygon feature class and the attribute table from the point layer was joined to the corresponding polygon within the feature class.
descript.purpose: To show the historical range of various forest types and disturbances (burns, heavy cut areas, etc.) within them at Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The intended use of all data in the park's GIS library is to support diverse park activities including planning, management, maintenance, research, and interpretation.
descript.supplinf: This is the less-detailed version of Miller's vegetation mapping work.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

attracc.attraccr: The Frank Miller map was drawn on a topographic base map. This base map was known to have some errors (in terms of exact coordinates) which were acknowledged by Miller himself. Some inferences were made. All data within this polygon layer was collected from the Miller Disturbance History Map Raster Images. Database domains were used for attribute information such as the forest type of each polygon. This procedure enhances attribute accuracy. GIS personnel verified all features and attributes by performing a 100% accuracy assessment, comparing all polygons within the feature class to the base map image. Much of the original map image was faded as the map was first created over 70 years ago. Only the highest percentage of verification was acceptable. Also it must be noted that the topographic base map was drawn in 1934. The boundary of the park has changed very much over the years. The extent which the polygon layer covers may include areas not within the park anymore and areas now within the park may not appear in the polygon layer.

dataqual.logic: This feature layer has been verified by several members of the staff at Twin Creeks Science Center, Great Smoky Mountains NP. A 100% accuracy assessment has been conducted to ensure this feature layer corresponds with the information displayed on the Miller Map Raster Images. Given the age and condition of the original image, the highest verification possible was needed.
dataqual.complete: The data includes all forest type polygons shown on the 1938 Miller Vegetation Map. All forest types displayed on the Miller Vegetation Map Raster Images are also shown in the polygon feature class. Within entity attributes there is more information about the various forest types and all other data displayed on map images.

horizpa.horizpar: The Frank Miller Vegetation map featured coordinates displaying the location of the park. The topographic base map on which Miller created his map of forest types was known to have some inconsistencies in portraying the topography of the park, especially in smaller drainages and ridges. When using these coordinates to georeference the map, some inferences were made. Residual errors for the two original raster images were minor but unavoidable.

citeinfo.origin: National Park Service, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Resource Mangement and Science
citeinfo.title: Miller Vegetation Map Raster Image

srcinfo.srccitea: Miller Vegetation and Disturbance History Map Raster Image
srcinfo.srccontr: Vector features class generated from digitizing the scanned images of Frank Miller's 1938 disturbance history map. Shapefile was then attributed data which came from the Miller map.

procstep.procdesc: The original Miller Vegetation Map Raster Images, of which there were two, were first Georeferenced based on the coordinates given on the map, then Clipped based on their coordinates, and lastly the Mosaic tool was employed to piece the map together.

cntperp.cntorg: National Park Service, Great Smoky Mountains National Park

procstep.procdesc: Polyline and point feature classes were created. Using the editor toolbar within ArcMap, the polyline layer was used to digitize the boundaries of all forest type areas on the map. The point layer was used to hold the attributes of each area.
procstep.srcused: Miller Vegetation and Disturbance History Map Raster Image
procstep.srcprod: Miller Vegetation and Disturbance History Polygon

cntperp.cntorg: National Park Service, Great Smoky Mountains National Park

procstep.procdesc: Upon completion of digitizing the map raster images, the polyline layer was converted to a polygon layer using the Feature to Polygon tool within ArcMap. Data was then verified by GIS personnel at Twin Creeks Science Center, Great Smoky Mountains NP. The polygon layer was compared to the map raster images. A 100% accuracy assessment was needed as much of the map was aged and faded.
procstep.srcused: Miller Vegetation and Disturbance History Map Raster Image
procstep.srcprod: Miller Vegetation and Disturbance History Polygon

cntperp.cntorg: National Park Service, Great Smoky Mountains National Park

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

enttyp.enttypl: Miller Map Vegetation and Disturbance History Polygon
enttyp.enttypd: Polygon Feature Class representative of the forest types within the park as of 1938
enttyp.enttypds: Scanned Images of the Frank Miller Vegetation and Disturbance History Map

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

codesetd.codesets: Areas which according to the map have experienced fires in the past.
Areas which according to the map have not experienced fires in the past.

attrvai.attrvae: All designations were derived directly from the map and Frank Miller's "Brief Narrative Descriptions of the Vegetative Types in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park"

attr.attrdefs: Frank Miller's 1938 Forest Types and Disturbance History Map, Great Smoky Mountains NP, Tennessee and North Carolina

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

overview.eaover: All features within the polygon feature class were derived from the Miller Vegetation and Disturbance History Map Raster Image. The designations applied to each polygon came from the map image also. More information was supplied by the "Brief Narrative Descriptions of the Vegetative Types in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park" issued by Frank Miller in 1938. Also it must be noted that the topographic base map, on which Miller created his vegetation map, was drawn in 1934. The boundary of the park has changed very much over the years. The extent which the polygon layer covers may include areas not within the park anymore and areas now within the park may not appear in the polygon layer.
overview.dsoverv: Polygon feature class showing the canopy-level vegetation and vegetation disturbances.

cntorgp.cntorg: National Park Service, Great Smoky Mountains National Park

distinfo.distliab: The National Park Service shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data and related graphics (i.e. GIF or JPG format files) are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such. The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. The related graphics are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not appropriate to use the related graphics as data. The National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an NPS server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on computer systems at the National Park Service , no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on other systems for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.
